Boil Order Lifted in Victor
Updated: Tue 2:39 PM, Jul 29, 2014

column2: var Title = ""Boil Order Lifted in Victor"";

column1: A boil order has been lifted for residents Victor and Goldfield.

The order was put in place after untreated water was run through the water system while fire crews fought a large fire. The order is in place as a precaution until the untreated water can be flushed from the system.
Walmart and the Teller County Office of Emergency Management donated bottled water for residents in the area.
Saturday's fire broke out at the Mining Union Hall in Victor around 3:15 p.m. It took fire crews from Victor, Cripple Creek, Divide and Colorado Springs nearly four hours to get it under control.
Crews were primarily concerned with containing the fire and keeping it from spreading to nearby buildings, said Lt. Marc Porcelli of the Teller County Sheriff's Office.
He says lightning may have started the fire.

Boil water order to be issued for part of Wilmington on Tuesday
CFPUA will be conducting multiple repairs while the boil order is effective

Wilmington | The Cape Fear Public Utility Authority is issuing a boil water order for part of Wilmington on Tuesday, according to a release.
The order covers the 800, 900 and 100 blocks of Castle and Queen streets, South Ninth and South 11th streets between Castle and Wooster streets, South 10th Street between Castle and Dawson streets.
Between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. Tuesday, residents are asked to boil water for at least a minute for use in any activity other than showering or bathing.
CFPUA will be conducting multiple repairs while the boil order is effective.
The advisory is being issued, CFPUA said in the release, because little or no pressure can allow bacteria to enter the water system.

– Adam Wagner

Beaches still closed at Shadow Cliffs due to E. coli levels
Park district doesn't have expected re-opening date
<a href=""/news/show_photo.php?main_id=13051&type=p&media_id=10392&section_id=1"" rel=""gb_pageset[gallery_13051]"" title=""Beaches still closed at Shadow Cliffs due to E. coli levels"">
People swimming at the Shadow Cliffs Lake north beach under ""Yellow Light"" warning Thursday, a day before it was closed due to higher-than-allowed E. coli levels. (Photo by Amanda Aguilar)
<a href=""/news/show_photo.php?main_id=13051&type=p&media_id=10393&section_id=1"" rel=""gb_pageset[gallery_13051]"" title=""Beaches still closed at Shadow Cliffs due to E. coli levels"">
Shadow Cliffs beaches have been closed due to high levels of E. coli bacteria measurement.
East Bay Regional Park District water management supervisor Hal MacLean said bacteria results did not meet state health standards.

The East Bay Regional Park District (EBRPD) closed the south beach Wednesday after bacteria results did not meet state health standards, and it extended the closure to the north beach on Friday after test results found water samples from there also exceeded allowable bacteria levels for swimming and other water contact, MacLean said.
""The results did not come back in our favor,"" said MacLean, adding that south beach's bacteria level was 6100 and north beach's was 1000 as of noon Friday.
The daily maximum level allowed under state standards is 235 (a figure that represents bacterial density per 100 mL of water).
MacLean said the low water level and not watering the lawn could be among the contributing factors leading to the high readings.
""We haven't been watering the lawn to conserve water,"" he said. ""So instead of the geese congregating on the lawn, they're congregating on the beach.""

The park district will continue to sample the water daily until the beaches are safe to reopen, MacLean said. In addition, they are talking to the health department to see ""what it will take to get it reopened,"" he added.
The rest of Shadow Cliffs is open, including the boating-launch area.
However, MacLean stressed the use of typical hygiene practices.
""Don't get water in your mouth. Wash your hands. Be cautious,"" he said.
The park district website has provided the public with a rating system of the water quality.

Boil-water order issued for Jay residents affected by line break
Share on Facebook
Tweet on Twitter
JAY — The Jay Village Water District has put out a boil-water order until further notice that will be in effect until a break in a water line on Smith Avenue is fixed and the water comes back on.
Only the customers who lost water need to boil it, district Treasurer Ron Moreau said.
The water line broke Friday morning and is a major break, he said. A crew has been on the scene trying to repair it since approximately 8 a.m.

Once water returns, the district is required to bring samples to a laboratory in Augusta to be tested for E. coli and coliform bacteria. The district will make an announcement when customers can stop boiling water.
Affected customers should boil water for one minute, Superintendent Mike Wells said last year. That includes water that they plan to drink, use to brush their teeth and make ice cubes.
After the water is boiled, it can be put in the refrigerator, Wells had said.
The water pipes are aging and are believed to be at least 60 years old. There were several breaks in the in lines in the Smith Avenue area.
District representatives were trying to get the word out about the boil-water order Friday.

Lake Quinsigamond beaches closed after sewage contamination found

column5: By Alli Knothe TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

column1:
WORCESTER — After discovering sewage contamination in Lake Quinsigamond, city officials have closed the beaches at Lake Park and Quinsigamond State Park to swimmers and urged the public to avoid contact with Lake Quinsigamond's water until it is neutralized.

The contamination was found Sunday afternoon and contained early Monday, the city wrote in a statement.

Contractors are working to determine the cause of the leak, which happened near the pump station at 83 Lake Ave., said John Hill, spokesman for the city.

While it happened during a period of heavy rains, contractors are looking into whether work being done at the pump station could have played a role. Mr. Hill said the site has seen a handful of overflows in recent years.

It takes 24 hours to get water quality test results, which are needed to allow the beaches to be reopened, Mr. Hill said. It is unclear when the water will be rendered safe.

""Bacteria and chemicals from the overflow can increase the risk of getting sick by consumption of contaminated water,"" the statement said. ""City officials will continue to monitor and sample water in the affected area to ensure recreational water quality standards are within acceptable limits before reopening the beaches for swimming.""

Meanwhile, Indian Lake remains closed as the city treats an algae bloom that popped up earlier this month. Public health officials have warned people not to fish, swim or otherwise come in contact with the water.
